content.title: Indigenous Animals of Sri Lanka
content.description: Find out about the rich biodiversity that Sri Lanka is blessed with

sections.heading: Indigenous Animals of Sri Lanka
sections.intro: Learn about our commitment to the conservation of endangered species. Discover the efforts being made to protect and preserve the unique fauna that calls Sri Lanka home.

items.title: Sri Lankan Junglefowl
items.description: The Sri Lankan junglefowl (Gallus lafayettii), sometimes known as Lafayette's junglefowl or Ceylon junglefowl, is a bird species native to Sri Lanka. It is the national bird of the country and is closely related to the more well-known red junglefowl.

items.title: Mugger Crocodile
items.description: The Mugger Crocodile (Crocodylus palustris) is the second biggest reptile in Sri Lanka. It is a medium-sized crocodilian species that lives in freshwater settings ranging from southern Iran to the Indian subcontinent and Sri Lanka.

items.title: Purple-faced Langur
items.description: The Purple-faced Langur (Semnopithecus vetulus), also recognized as the Purple-faced Leaf Monkey, is an arboreal monkey native to Sri Lanka, characterized by its lengthy tail.

sections.heading: National Parks of Sri Lanka
sections.intro: Are you ready to observe these magnificent animals in their natural habitats? Learn more about Sri Lanka's wildlife by visiting the following national parks.

items.title: Yala National Park
items.description: Yala National Park, situated in Sri Lanka, provides tourists the chance to view different wildlife, including Sri Lankan leopards, elephants, sloth bears, and many bird species.

items.title: Wilpattu National Park
items.description: Wilpattu National Park, set in northwest Sri Lanka, lets you witness diverse wildlife like leopards, elephants, sloth bears, and various bird species.
